#Text=Lincoln
#Text=Park ( New Jersey )
#Text=Lincoln Park is a borough in Morris County , New Jersey .
#Text=It is the easternmost municipality in Morris County , and it has a population of about 10,521 people .
#Text=Understand
#Text=The community that is now Lincoln Park has existed since colonial times .
#Text=This small community further grew with the construction of the Delaware , Lackawanna , and Western Railroad 's Boonton Branch ( present-day Montclair-Boonton Line ) .
#Text=It was formerly part of neighboring Pequannock .
#Text=The borough was founded as a township under the name Beavertown on March 11 , 1922 .
#Text=The town was reincorporated as the borough of Lincoln Park in February 26 , 1925 .
#Text=It was named after President Abraham Lincoln .
#Text=By car
#Text=U.S. Route 202 is the primary road through the borough , linking it with Montville and Wayne .
#Text=Comly/Ryerson Road link the borough to Pequannock , while Chapel Hill/Pine Brook/Two Bridges Road link it to Fairfield .
#Text=Lincoln Park can also be easily accessed from Interstates 80 and 287 , as well as U.S. Route 46 and New Jersey Route 23 using these roads .
#Text=By bus
#Text=NJ Transit provides service from Mondays to Saturdays on the 871 bus route to Willowbrook Mall in Wayne and Morristown .
#Text=Buses in each direction arrive four times per day .
#Text=One can transfer to an express bus bound for Port Authority Bus Terminal at Willowbrook .
#Text=Lakeland Buses
#Text=also provides occasional service on weekdays , with buses heading directly to New York City in early mornings , and buses on the return trip arriving in the late evening .
#Text=By train
#Text=The Montclair-Boonton Line has a station in the borough .
#Text=This is not the best way , however , as trains are limited to weekday rush hour service , and a transfer is required further down the line in order to reach New York Penn Station .
#Text=This will not be a problem however if you are arriving from Hoboken .
#Text=Additionally , the station is not wheelchair accessible due to its odd layout .
#Text=Mountain View
#Text=station , although it has equally lousy service , is also close to Lincoln Park ( and ADA-compliant , too ! ) .
#Text=However , it is relatively far from the center of the borough .
#Text=Get around
#Text=Driving by car is the only quick way to get around .
#Text=Walking around the center of the borough is easy , as it is relatively small in size .
#Text=Walking up certain roads can be quite a workout however , as they cross over Hook Mountain , which is part of the Watchung Mountain group .
#Text=There are multiple bus stops around , but bus service is rare , making it an impractical way to get around .
#Text=See
#Text=John Dods Tavern
#Text=, 8 Chapel Hill Rd ( Next to the main business district ) .
#Text=This old tavern was built in 1770 , and it has since become a dentist 's office .
#Text=It was mentioned as a landmark for routes in letters sent to George Washington by his allies .
#Text=The Two Bridges
#Text=.

#Text=This area was once referred to as the " two Bridges " , or " the Fork of Passaic " , in Revolutionary War letters ; one of the bridges is today used as the main route linking the borough with Fairfield .
#Text=The area directly adjacent to it was also used as a Revolutionary War campsite .
#Text=Do
#Text=Walk along the old Morris Canal .
#Text=The historic Morris Canal formerly ran through the borough , and its remnants are still scattered along its former path .
#Text=The proper way to walk along the Morris Canal in Lincoln Park is to take the bus to or park your car near the bridge over the Pompton River .
#Text=Then , walk along U.S. Route 202 until you reach the Main Street intersection . Cross Main Street then proceed to walk along Beaverbrook Road .
#Text=Turn left when you reach the entrance to the condos and you will notice a large board demarcating the canal 's path .
#Text=Cross the road with care , and walk the remainder of the right-of-way via a portion of the Morris Canal Greenway .
#Text=This will take you to Plane 10 East , located on the Montville border .
#Text=Eat
#Text=Noches de Colombia
#Text=, 466 Boonton Turnpike , ☏ +1 973-832-7720 .
#Text=Colombian restaurant with catering and car delivery .
#Text=Serves great Pandebono .
#Text=Sleep
#Text=There are no places to stay in Lincoln Park .
#Text=Therefore , you must stay in other towns .
#Text=There are hotels in Fairfield and Wayne where Lincoln Park can be easily reached .
#Text=Cope
#Text=The local newspaper is The Star-Ledger , along with others .
#Text=The town is served by radio and TV stations mostly in New York .
#Text=Go next
#Text=Paterson
#Text=Newark
#Text=Jersey City
#Text=New York City
